sentence-detokenized: EU rejects German call for boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagreed with Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists have determined whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

The German representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until the scientific evidence was clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we do not see any reasons for it," said Commission spokesperson Nikolaus van der Pas at a press conference.
He said further scientific research was needed and if it was found that action was needed, the European Union should take it.

EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler's proposal last month to ban sheep brains, spleen and spinal cord from the human and animal food chain is a very specific and precautionary measure to protect human health, he said.
Fischler proposed EU-wide measures following reports from the UK and France that sheep can contract Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease - under laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to reconsider his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee, the national animal health officials, questioned whether such a measure was justified given the low risk to human health.
Earlier, at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio had accused Fischler of raising unjustified alarm by making "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and Britain supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's scientific veterinary committees and multidisciplinary committees will revisit the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
It has long been known that sheep can contract scrapie, a brain-damaging disease similar to BSE that is thought to have been transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep posed a risk to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could influence consumers across Europe.
"We have to be very careful about how other countries adopt the German example," Welsh Farmers Union (NFU) leader John Lloyd Jones told BBC radio.

Bonn has spearheaded efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March following a British report suggesting that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease from eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of the total imports.
There were 4,275 tonnes of British mutton imported, representing about 10% of total imports.
Rare Hendrix song design sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare, early handwritten draft of a song by US guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite pieces on Thursday.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for the draft of "Ain't no telling" that Hendrix had written on a London hotel stationery in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in January 1967 in the English city of Nottingham, he threw the piece of paper into the audience, where it was caught by a fan.
Buyers also snapped up 16 other items offered for auction by Hendrix's former girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
Among them was a box inlaid with black lacquer and mother-of-pearl in which Hendrix kept his drugs, purchased by an anonymous Australian buyer for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is disrupting the atmosphere for talks.
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for a resumption of talks on the Taiwan Strait with Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which angered Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said the time was ripe for political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters: "The necessary atmosphere for the opening of the talks has been disrupted by the Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's top negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a visiting group from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to hold political talks....
that is, to end the state of hostility," the overseas edition of People's Daily quoted Tang as saying on Thursday.

Shen of the Foreign Ministry said in an interview with Reuters Television news agency that he had read the reports of Tang's remarks, but gave no details on why the negotiator felt the time was right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a breakaway province.
China, which has long resisted all efforts by Taipei to gain greater international recognition, was angered by a visit by Taiwanese Vice President Lien to Ukraine this week.
China says the time is ripe for Taiwan talks.
China has said that it is time to hold political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps in this direction.

Consultations should be held to determine the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, vice-chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, as saying late on Wednesday.
German car registrations in July 14.2 % higher than in the same month last year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
German new vehicle registrations rose by 14.2 per cent in July this year compared to the same period last year, the Federal Motor Transport Authority announced on Thursday.
According to the Office, 356,725 vehicles were newly registered in July 1996 - 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks.
The figures represent an increase of 13.6 percent for cars and a decrease of 2.2 percent for trucks compared to July 1995.
The registration of motorbikes increased by 32.7 percent during this period.
The increase was partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German car manufacturers recorded an increase in registrations during this period.
Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Together with General Motors, Opel AG took second place with 49,269 registrations, which corresponds to a share of 16.4 percent.
Ford follows in third place with 35,563 registrations, which corresponds to a share of 11.7 percent.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 than in July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5522 registrations in July last year.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
THE GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE PRIME MINISTER THE GREEN LIGHT FOR THE ELECTIONS.
The party executive of the Greek Socialists has given Prime Minister Costas Simitis the green light to call early elections, their General Secretary Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a cabinet meeting on Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens News Bureau +301 3311812-4

Israel plays down fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appeared to be a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who led unsuccessful negotiations with Syria as Israeli ambassador in Washington, told Israeli radio that it looked as if Damascus wanted to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that the {(1)[MISC] Syrian priority} is still to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they are definitely tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovich ends his term as ambassador.
His successor is Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
Israel sent a message to Syria through Washington on Wednesday saying it was committed to peace and wanted to start negotiations without preconditions.
However, it accused Damascus of creating a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria accused Israel on Wednesday of launching a hysterical campaign against the country after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently fired a missile test.
She explained that her arms purchases were for defence purposes.

"The message we have sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready to enter into peace negotiations at any time and without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have increased since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June promising to keep the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
The Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have been deadlocked since 1991, although the previous government was willing to make concessions on the Golan.
The last peace talks between the two sides took place in February.
"The voices coming out of Damascus are bad, not good.
The media...
are full of expressions and statements that must be disturbing....
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it could become its prisoners," said Levy.
"We expect Syria, if it is turned towards peace, to respond to Israel's message to start peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
No one benefits from wars. "
The Israeli television station Channel Two said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
She did not give a source for this report.
Netanyahu's and Levy's spokespersons said they could not confirm this.
Television also reported that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria via Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies nurses stranded in Libya.
A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a report in the Polish tabloid that Libya had denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who wanted to return home after working in the North African country.
"That is not true.

To date, we have no knowledge of any nurse being held in Libya without her will, nor have we received any complaint," the chargé d'affaires of the Polish embassy in Tripoli, Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, told Reuters by phone.

The Polish Ministry of Labour announced this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate the matter. However, Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted because some nurses had complained about their working conditions and the non-payment of their salaries.
He said that there are an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq pledged on Thursday to support Kurdish rebels in Iran after they were attacked by Iranian troops deep in Iraq last month.

A statement by the Mujahideen Khalq said its leader Massoud Rajavi met with the secretary general of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI) Hassan Rastegar in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed his support for the insurgent Kurds in Iran.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand shoulder to shoulder with its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan.
A spokesperson for the group said the meeting signalled "a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition groups".
In pursuit of the KDPI guerrillas based in Iraq's Kurdish areas outside the control of the government in Baghdad, Iran bombed targets in northern Iraq on a massive scale in July.
The Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are controlled by guerrillas of the Iraqi Kurdish group Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish groups, have been in control of northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
The weekend saw the heaviest fighting between the two parties since a US-backed ceasefire last year.
The Mujahideen Khalq said Iranian troops had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniya province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
According to their own statements, about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are flying air and ground strikes on targets in northern Iraq to fight their own Kurdish rebels.
A US-led air force in southern Turkey protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by troops in Baghdad.
The Saudi riyal exchange rate remains stable in quiet summer trading.
The Saudi riyal against the dollar and interest rates on riyal deposits in interbank trading remained broadly stable this week in quiet summer trading, traders in the Kingdom said.
"There were no changes in the Saudi riyal's rates.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one trader.
The spot riyal was set at 3.7504 / 06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8 per cent, three-month at 5-5/8, 1/2 per cent and six-month at 5-3/4, 5/8 per cent.
One-year funds were at six, 5-7/8 per cent.
Israel authorises Arafat's escape to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory into the West Bank on Thursday, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the PLO, an adviser to Arafat said.
"The problem is solved.
The president's plane has been given permission to fly through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank until Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in Ramallah in the West Bank on Thursday, but the meeting place was moved to Gaza after Israel denied the Palestinian leader's helicopters permission to fly.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to prevent the meeting in Ramallah by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO representatives on civil affairs at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat meets Peres after flight ban in Gaza.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after the right-wing Israeli government prevented the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister, according to Palestinian sources.

Japan's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that in his opinion the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is aimed at safeguarding economic growth, has not changed after the release of the central bank's "Tankan" survey.
